text: I love the rural parts of our country. I think we should stand up for people who work the land. Full stop. That said, American political culture's fetishization of the rural is profoundly unhelpful if you believe in a government of the PEOPLE.

text: When the London bureau closed in '05, correspondent Todd Richissin said the paper "splurged for the foreign bureaus," unusual for mid-sized metro dailies. "It was a mark of prestige," he said. "They considered it important and they had the money to do it."
author: jlupf

text: Former Sun Rome bureau chief Weldon Wallace covered a territory "greater than Alexander's Empire since it included the Middle East and Africa as well as Italy and the Eastern Mediterranean nations."
author: jlupf

text: At one time, @baltimoresun had bureaus in Mexico City, Berlin, Tokyo, Moscow, Beijing, London, New Delhi, and Rome. That's pretty neat!
author: jlupf

text: Glad you are there. Glad she is there. TV public affairs content is a tough business with totally jacked incentives. But you have to be there!

text: Glad to see. I’m neutral but impressed. In particular, I admire his commitment to run an honest campaign and treat his people right.

text: I welcome the elite media Harvard socialists to vote for left candidates in Dem primaries. Fund them. Write articles and op-eds about them. But this is really rich. Just because Jonathan Alter put a fruit rollup in your lunchbox one day doesn’t mean you grew up poor.

text: She has never experienced American prosperity. I bet it was really rough writing for the Harvard Crimson.

text: I assume this tweet has been sufficiently dunked on, but is this offensive to people who have actually experienced material deprivation? I ask because I didn’t grow up poor and wouldn’t claim to know what that’s like even though I ate processed food snacks a lot

text: Anyway, plenty to quibble with here. But hopefully people can at least affirm the sincerity & good intentions. Especially as they relate to communitarian principles and concern for the well-being of Americans who are hurting and cut off from prosperity and flourishing. //END
author: jlupf

text: I think this is the saddest and most dangerous aspect of it all. The people who say they care most about life, marriage, and family are being seduced by a vile, toxic, and racist political coalition. #NeverTrump needs to offer them much more – concrete assurances that they matter
author: jlupf

text: One thing they might’ve emphasized even more: the Republican resistance to Trumpism, however small and however honorable, seems to be moving on from the past consensus’s lip service to social-conservative concerns.
author: jlupf

text:
It’s a sweeping statement considering the 2016 election turned on 80,000 votes in 3 states or whatever, and they’d be singing a different song had Mrs Clinton won an Electoral College majority.

But Trump and conservative moral rot would’ve outlasted 2016 even so.
author: jlupf

text: I have my doubts that they will ever shed their attachments to pro-rich Republicanism, but if their aesthetic and philosophical fondness for communitarianism would ever be matched by material, political commitments to it, I think this could be a movement for good.
author: jlupf

text: Kind of handicaps itself by moralizing so strongly after saying that some of them welcomed Trumpism. But not all of them did, and there are fair points here, including a stated desire to help our countrymen that didn’t become (like most of them) jet-setting global citizens.
author: jlupf

text: Interesting statement by a group of conservatives, writers and editors mostly, forcefully saying goodbye and basically good riddance to the pre-2016 consensus of right wing ideas and GOP platform planks that held the Right together.

text: Same issue with clergy candidates, which I was when I ran in ‘07. Of course it’s true that clergy spouses, children, and candidates are laity. So are lay employees of agencies and judicatories. But all are overrepresented in UM ACs and GCs, diluting vote of “ordinary” laypeople.

text:
Review of @TrumpDC men’s room, ground level by Starbucks. Missing and moldy caulking everywhere. Tiles are only on some walls (Cheap!) Drywall is lowest quality. Badly hung. Missing paint in some places. All pre-fab, nothing custom. Not pictured: Filthy doors.

Rating: ★☆☆☆☆

Right. The VSG data finds higher social capital, warmer feelings on race and immigration, and lower Trump support for active churchgoers.

text: Yes. Need to recruit pro-life or abortion-moderate state legislators or political newcomers to take out entrenched Democrats in congressional primaries.

text: If the goal is winning, I’m afraid you have to go with the all-around centrist. But if the goal is forcing a debate in the party and in the country, then the far left pro-life Democrat would definitely challenge a the status quo & a platform written for and by today’s Dem elites.
author: jlupf

text: I would run to the left of everyone: Reparations, 70% top marginal rate, etc... And European-style abortion restrictions. Make the DSA support Sanders or Warren so they can keep abortion in the 40th week.
author: jlupf

text: But a top-tier @prolifedem candidate would need to get serious about 2020 right now, lest the party dodge a desperately needed debate and the country miss the chance to counter the noxious idea that if you care about the unborn you have to support Trumpism.

text: There’s still time for a pro-life or abortion-moderate Dem to enter the wide open 2020 field. @CCamosy argues that there’s a lane a mile wide.

text: I am in awe of the imagination(s) that created the story. Love the costumes, scenery, & set design. Such good character development & dialogue. Could do without so much wanton & gratuitous violence. Hate the sci-fi/fantasy aspects. Would be better as straight historical fiction.
